Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 2015 SIAM International Conference on Data Mining

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The 2015 SIAM International Conference on Data Mining (SDM 2015) is being organized by the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) in cooperation with the American Statistical Association. SDM 2015 will be held in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada on April 30th to May 2nd, 2015. This premier conference provides a venue for researchers who are addressing problems in data mining to present their work in a peer-reviewed forum. It is widely attended by researchers and practitioners in the field. Participation in premier research conferences in data mining is an integral component of the training of Ph.D. students in data mining. The SDM 2015 Ph.D. Student Forum is aimed at providing an opportunity for Ph.D. candidates to present their work and receive constructive feedback and mentoring from established researchers in data mining. Such feedback and mentoring is expected to improve the quality of the students' thesis research. Similarly, student recipients of a travel award will be able to attend technical sessions, plenary talks, panels, tutorials and workshops. They will interact with peers who share similar interests from other universities, as well as hundreds of leading researchers in data mining from around the world. This experience will be extremely formative and fruitful towards the shaping of their future research endeavors.

Institution.Name: University of Notre Dame
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant provided for support for 35 students from US universities to attend the SIAM Data Mining Conference, as well as the Doctoral Consortium. About 25% of the supported students were women.  The students participated in various activities, including presentation, peer-networking, mentor-mentee activities, and the doctoral consortium.

The doctoral student forum consisted of a poster session, where the Ph.D. student forum participants presented their work, interacted with their peers from other universities as well as hundreds of leading researchers in data mining from around the world. Each student was assigned a senior researcher to serve as a mentor on a variety of career-related issues.

The significant outcomes were opportunity to Ph.D. candidates, from the US univieristies, to present their work and receive constructive feedback and mentoring from established researchers in data mining. The poster session provided a dedicated venue for all students to receive more elaborate feedback on their respective papers and presentations. Such feedback and mentoring is expected to improve the quality of the students thesis research. The students attended the technical sessions, ple-ary talks, panels, tutorials and workshops of their choice at the conference. In addition, they also took leadership on generating a discussion on the papers and research in social media. These students will be the leaders in the field tomorrow, and this funding enabled a mentorship, networking, and feedback opportunity.
